tossups.question: The second emperor of this dynasty came to power after Zhao Gao forged an edict ordering their older brother to commit suicide. The founder of this dynasty narrowly avoided assassination by a blind lute player, and was earlier targeted by Jing Ke while head of one of the Warring States. Sima Qian claimed that this dynasty (*) burned books and murdered scholars who opposed Legalism, and its first emperor’s extreme paranoia led him to ingest mercury in the hopes of achieving immortality. He was ultimately unsuccessful, and was entombed with the Terracotta Army. For ten points, name this first imperial Chinese dynasty, founded by Shi Huangdi.
tossups.answer: Qin Dynasty [accept Qíncháo, do not accept “Jin Dynasty” or “Xin Dynasty” or “Qing Dynasty”]

tossups.question: In a novel in this language, the title character finds solace in the humanitist philosophy of his friend Quincas Borba. In addition to The Posthumous Memoirs of Bras Cubas, the King of Ward Three is stabbed with a pair of scissors in a work in this language. The Gospel According to Jesus Christ was written in this language, as was a novel featuring a former prostitute who wears dark (*) glasses. That novel in this language opens at a traffic intersection and centers on a doctor's wife who is not stricken by a “white sickness.” Blindness was written in, for ten points, what language used by Jose Saramago and many Brazilian authors?

The dadgah and behram types of this are held in different degrees of reverence by followers of one religion. Some Christians believe that the “Holy” version of this substance appears above Christ’s tomb every Great Saturday. During Hindu marriages, the bride and groom take (*) seven steps around this substance in the saptapadi ritual. Offerings during yajna rituals are often made to the Hindu god of this substance, Agni. For ten points, name this substance that is found in Zoroastrian temples, where it is often used in purification rituals along with its counterpart water.

One of these substances is reacted with an alcohol in the first step of the Williamson ether synthesis. These substances react with a hydrogen substituent of an alkyl halide in an E2 reaction. By definition, nucleophiles act as these substances. Sodium hydride acts as a very strong example of these substances. Adding these substances to (*) phenolphthalein results in a pink solution. In one definition for these substances, they are defined as electron pair donors, while Bronsted-Lowry theory defines these substances as proton acceptors. These substances are exemplified by ammonia and lye. For ten points, name these substances that have a pH of greater than 7, unlike acids.
tossups.answer: bases [accept Lewis bases or Bronsted-Lowry bases; anti-prompt on nucleophiles until it is mentioned with “what other type of substance do nucleophiles typically function as?”]

tossups.question: This poet recommended that parricide be punished by the consumption of garlic rather than of hemlock in one of his Epodes. In a poem sometimes named for Cleopatra, this author wrote that “now is the time to drink.” This author included a poem boasting that he had “built a monument more lasting than bronze” in his most famous collection. In one work, this author praised Homer for beginning his narration (*) in medias res rather than ab ovo, and Wilfred Owen used a line from one of this author’s works for the title of his poem, “Dulce et decorum est.” For ten points, name this Roman author of Odes and the Ars Poetica, who coined the phrase “carpe diem.”

Glacial grooves carved during the Ice Age can be found in this lake’s Kelleys Island. This lake’s Pelee Island is home to an annual fall pheasant hunt that attracts tourists from all over the world. The Maumee and Sandusky rivers empty into this lake which is home to Presque Isle, the site of a crucial (*) Oliver Hazard Perry victory during the War of 1812. The Ontario city of Port Stanley can be found on the shores of this lake, which shares its name with a city in northwest Pennsylvania. The Niagara River is the main outflow of this lake. For ten points, Cleveland is situated on what Great Lake?

This politician’s foreign policy was mocked in a letter written by Dupuy De Lome. This president’s Secretary of War Russell Alger was heavily criticized for purchasing “embalmed beef” from Chicago meatpacking companies. Under this president, the Teller Amendment forbade the U.S. from annexing (*) Cuba. This man ordered Commander George Dewey to Manila Bay following the explosion of the USS Maine. Under this president’s leadership, the United States acquired the Philippines after victory in the Spanish-American War. Theodore Roosevelt succeeded, for ten points, what president assassinated by Leon Czolgosz in 1901?

Santiago Calatrava designed a winery in this country that resembles a sine wave. A palace in this country includes a courtyard featuring a massive pool and an arch decorated with scallops, known as the Court of Myrtles. One architect from this country used mosaics in the The House of Bones and el drac, a statue of a salamander outside Park (*) Güell [gwell], which is in this country. An unfinished 18-spire cathedral in this country was originally designed by Antoni Gaudi in 1883. That building, which is scheduled to be finished in 2026, is the Sagrada Familia. For ten points, name this country, home to the Alhambra and the city of Barcelona.
tossups.answer: Kingdom of Spain [or Reino de España; the building in the first line is the Ysios Winery]

tossups.question: The L2 [L-two] norm of a metric space is derived from an application of this formula. Values that satisfy this formula are generated from a set of equations derived from evaluating the function z-squared at the lattice points of the complex plane. This formula is used to calculate the radial value in (*) polar coordinates when given Cartesian coordinates. Applying this formula to a set of points in the x-y plane gives the distance formula. Sets of positive integers that obey this formula are known as its namesake “triples.” For ten points, name this geometric theorem of right triangles, commonly stated as a-squared plus b-squared equals c-squared.
tossups.answer: Pythagorean theorem [anti-prompt on Euclidean distance formula until it is mentioned with “what simpler formula is used to derive it?”]

tossups.question: A cantata by this composer that was based off of a poem by John Dryden contrasts a scene of “Orpheus [leading] the savage race” with the title saint “[raising] the wonder high” before ending with a grand chorus. This composer of Ode for St. Cecilia’s Day included the largo alla siciliana La Paix movement in a piece written for the end of the War of the Austrian Succession. The tenor aria (*) “Ev’ry valley shall be exalted” is sung in Part I of an oratorio by this composer. That oratorio by this composer of Music for the Royal Fireworks contains the “Hallelujah” chorus at the end of its second part. For ten points, name this Baroque composer of Messiah.

In this novel, a character who is taught by Colonel Campbell is cared for by a woman who is cruelly told she must restrict herself to three dull statements by the main character during a picnic at Box Hill. In addition to the spinster Miss Bates, this novel features a character who is gifted a piano by and marries Frank Churchill, Jane Fairfax. This novel's title character attempts to match (*) Mr. Elton with her best friend, who ultimately marries Robert Martin. This novel's title character is friends with Harriet Smith and eventually marries Mr. Knightley. For ten points, name this book about Miss Woodhouse, a novel by Jane Austen.

In 1968, this man launched the War of Attrition in order to reclaim territory his country had lost the year prior. Charles Keightly led an assault on Port Said in response to one of this man’s actions. After accusing Mohamed Naguib of supporting the Muslim Brotherhood, this man united his country with (*) Syria in the short-lived United Arab Republic. This man, who asked the USSR to fund the construction of the Aswan High Dam, expelled Jews after Dwight Eisenhower forced France, Britain, and Israel to stop their invasion of his country during the Suez Canal crisis. Anwar Sadat succeeded, for ten points, what Egyptian president?

This thinker postulated that we cannot distinguish reality from illusion through our senses in his “dream argument.” Dedicated to Christina of Sweden, this man’s last published work discussed emotions and was titled Passions of the Soul. This philosopher argued the essential properties of an object can only be perceived through pure reason in the (*) melting wax argument and he described the mind and body as separable in his namesake dualism. Meditations on First Philosophy was written by, for 10 points, what French philosopher who wrote “I think, therefore I am?”
tossups.answer: René Descartes [accept words based on his name like Cartesian]

tossups.question: This artist discussed a dispute with one of his patrons in The Gentle Art of Making Enemies. This artist painted The Gold Scab to criticize Frederick Leyland after conflicts over his designs for The Peacock Room. This artist was criticized for “flinging a pot of paint in the public’s face” with the last of his London (*) Nocturnes, for which he sued art critic John Ruskin for libel. The subject of another work by this man wears a white bonnet and sits with her side to the viewer. For ten points, name this artist whose Arrangement in Grey and Black is a portrait of his mother.

The Gap Band were credited as authors of a song titled for this place after similarities with “Oops Upside Your Head” were revealed. In a Drake song titled for this place, the singer claims “I see all this money through my Ohio State Buckeyes.” The singer awaits the day when his “ship comes in” so he can bring the title figure out of her “white bread world” in a (*) Billy Joel song titled for this place. In a song titled for this place, the singer tells Julio to “get the stretch.” That song titled for this place describes being “too hot” and making a “dragon wanna retire, man.” For ten points, name this place, whose funk is described in a Mark Ronson song featuring Bruno Mars.

It’s not Scotland, but a scientist from this country theorized a “demon” that could know the position and momentum of every particle in the universe. Another scientist from this country coined the term solenoid, the magnetic field of which can be solved using his namesake law. A law regarding the curl of the magnetic field was formulated by a scientist from this country, to which (*) James Clerk Maxwell added a displacement current. Scientists from this country name the SI units of current and pressure. For ten points, name this home country of Pierre-Simon Laplace [la-PLAHSS], Andre-Marie Ampere [am-PAIR], and Blaise Pascal.

Johann Patkul’s instigation of this conflict led to him being executed on a breaking wheel. The Treaty of Altranstadt that was signed during this conflict forced the abdication of Augustus the Strong. One country’s navy has always maintained the ship Gangut in commemoration of a naval victory during this conflict. (*) Ivan Mazepa defected to the losing side in this war, which was ended by the Treaty of Nystad. During this conflict, Charles XII’s forces faced a decisive defeat at the Battle of Poltava. For ten points, name this war in which Peter the Great’s Russian-led coalition defeated Sweden.
tossups.answer: Great Northern War [accept Second Northern War; prompt on just Northern War]

tossups.question: Xochiquetzal translates as “precious flower [one of these objects],” and Kukulkan was the Yucatec Mayan equivalent of one god associated with them. In Slavic lore, Prince Ivan was given one of these objects so bright it could light up a room. Coatlicue was impregnated by a (*) ball of these objects before giving birth to Huitzilopochtli, and the Norse goddess Freya possessed a coat covered with these objects. In the Egyptian underworld, the hearts of the dead were weighed against one of these things belonging to Ma’at that represented truth. Quezalcoatl was a serpent covered in, for ten points, what objects usually found on birds?
tossups.answer: feathers [do not accept or prompt on “wings”]

tossups.question: This author wrote about a Viking king in a subsection of a larger work entitled “The Saga of King Olav.” This author wrote a poem in dactylic hexameter that ends with the title character's discovery of Gabriel Lajeunesse [law-djun-ess] in Philadelphia. That work by this author opens by describing “the forest primeval” and tells the story of (*) Evangeline. The main character of a poem by this author sees a "phantom ship" and is told about lanterns in the line "one if by land and two if by sea." For ten points, name this American poet of the collection Tales of a Wayside Inn, including the poem Paul Revere's Ride.

A version of this technique separates samples by their isoelectric point and can be performed in its two-dimensional variant. Capillary action moves the results of this technique onto a nitrocellulose membrane in a Southern Blot. The amphipathic nature of sodium dodecyl sulfate allows it to separate both polar and nonpolar sections during the preparation for one variant for this technique, after which it is placed in (*) polyacrylamide [PAUL-lee-uh-KRILL-uh-MIDE]. Samples in this technique are most often placed in the polysaccharide agarose, which contains wells for the samples near the anode. For ten points, name this technique which uses electricity to separate DNA fragments by size.
tossups.answer: gel electrophoresis [accept 2-D gel electrophoresis or sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis or SDS-PAGE]

tossups.question: In this novel, the narrator compares his skills to those of the pirate William Dampier. After calling up the ghosts of several historical figures, this novel’s title character learns that Alexander the Great died from excessive drinking.  In this novel, members of the Grand Academy of Lagado attempt to soften marble and extract sunbeams from (*) cucumbers. In the first section of this novel, the narrator documents a conflict between the Little-Endians and the Big-Endians over how to crack an egg correctly in Lilliput. For ten points, name this satirical novel by Jonathan Swift in which the title character visits several fantastical lands.
tossups.answer: Gulliver’s Travels [or Travels into Several Remote Nations of the World. In Four Parts. By Lemuel Gulliver, First a Surgeon, and then a Captain of Several Ships]

bonuses.leadin: Take some advice from the Wu-Tang Clan and diversify your bonds. For ten points each:
answer: interest rate [accept bond yield; accept specific types of interest rates]
parts: U.S. government bonds are also known as “notes” or “securities” from this Cabinet department. This department also controls the U.S. Mint.
A bond’s duration approximately measures how its value changes as this quantity changes. The Taylor rule sets a guideline for this quantity given a country’s GDP growth rate.

The buying and selling of bonds and the setting of interest rates are two of the tools of this type of economic policy, representing the decisions made by a central bank. Unlike fiscal policy, it does not involve government legislation.

bonuses.leadin: Several works by Georgia O’Keeffe, including “Black Cross, New Mexico,” are on display in this city’s Art Institute. For ten points each:
answer: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte [or Un Dimanche après-midi à l’Île de la Grande Jatte]
parts: Name this midwestern city, the most populous in Illinois. Anish Kapoor’s sculpture “Cloud Gate” is in this city’s Millenium Park
This Spanish artist’s sculpture The Sun, The Moon, and One Star is also located in Chicago. A museum dedicated to this artist of Catalan Landscape and The Tilled Field is located in Barcelona.

This large pointillist work by Georges Seurat, which mostly depicts people relaxing on the banks of the Seine, is currently housed in the Art Institute of Chicago. A woman holds an umbrella and a monkey on a leash on the right side of this painting.

bonuses.leadin: In Vaclav Havel’s essay “The Czech Lot," he gave a scathing review of this author, calling him “blithely skeptical." For ten points each:
answer: robots [accept Rossum’s Universal Robots; accept Three Laws of Robotics]
parts: Name this author who described the lives of characters such as the surgeon Tomas, his photographer wife Tereza, and the bowler-hat-donning artist Sabina in the novel The Unbearable Lightness of Being.
Milan Kundera’s first novel was The Joke, in which Ludvik Jahn gets in trouble for writing that this concept “is the opium of the people” on a postcard.

Karel Capek [karl chop eck], another Czech author, coined this term in his play R.U.R., which features two of the title technological entities, Marius and Sulla. Isaac Asimov wrote three laws that apply to these entities and a series named after them.

bonuses.leadin: The second phase of a revolution in this country was signaled by the song “Grândola, Vila Morena.” For ten points each:
answer: The Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste [accept East Timor]
European Union [accept European Economic Community; prompt on European Community]
parts: Name this European country, where, in 1974, a regime known as the Estado Novo was overthrown by the relatively peaceful Carnation Revolution. Antonio Salazar led this country until incapacitated by a stroke in 1968.

Also in 1974, Portugal functionally abandoned this then-colony, which was promptly invaded by its neighbor. This Southeast Asian country’s current President, Francisco Guterres, is from the Fretilin party.
Portugal joined this regional organization in 1986, before this organization was officially formed by the 1992 Treaty of Maastricht. The UK officially withdrew from this organization in January 2020.

bonuses.leadin: The most common treatment for this disease uses the dopamine precursor L-DOPA. For ten points each:
parts: Name this neurodegenerative disease that is characterized by tremors and muscle stiffness. Neurons affected by this disease contain clumps of the protein alpha-synuclein known as Lewy bodies.

One hypothesis as to the cause of Parkinson’s disease, the Braak model, suggests that the disease progresses similarly to one caused by these agents. These misfolded proteins are also responsible for kuru and mad cow disease.

The decline in the function of this neurotransmitter and calcium ions is thought to contribute to the accumulation of Lewy bodies. This molecule is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system.

bonuses.leadin: In a poem set during a modest funeral, this poet described a dead woman’s cloth onto which she had embroidered birds. For ten points each:
answer: swans [accept “Invective Against Swans” or “The Wild Swans at Coole”]
William Butler Yeats [yates] [or W. B. Yeats]
parts: Name this American poet of “The Emperor of Ice Cream.” This poet also asked why “thin men of Haddam” were unable to see the title bird in “Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird.”

A Wallace Stevens poem titled “Invective Against [these birds]” describes the soul flying “beyond the parks / And far beyond the discords of the wind.” A different poet described seeing a group of these animals whose "hearts have not grown old" at Coole.

This Irish poet of “The Wild Swans at Coole” depicted the rape of Leda by Zeus in “Leda and the Swan.” This poet also described how “the falcon cannot hear the falconer” as “things fall apart; the center cannot hold” in his poem “The Second Coming.”

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer some questions involving gold and Norse myth:
parts: The goddess Idunn controls golden fruits of this type that give youth to those who consume them. In Greek mythology, the garden of the Hesperides has golden fruits of this type.
This goddess was given a golden headpiece by the Sons of Ivaldi after Loki cut off her hair. This wife of Thor has a daughter named Thrud.
A golden tree called Glasir stands in front of this location, and this place has a roof made of golden shields. In Norse myth, half of those who die in battle go to this place ruled by Odin.

bonuses.leadin: The rocket equation adjusts this law for a system with non-constant mass. For ten points each:
answer: Newton’s second law of motion [prompt on Newton’s laws of motion]
mass moment of inertia [prompt on I; do not accept or prompt on “inertia”]
parts: Name this law, which states that the time derivative of linear momentum is equal to the net force applied. This law of classical mechanics is more commonly stated as force equals mass times acceleration.

For a rotational system, Newton’s second law states that torque is equal to the angular acceleration multiplied by this quantity. This quantity is equal to mass times distance squared for a revolving point mass.

This equation is used to find the moment of inertia for an object whose rotational axis does not go through its center of mass. A term of "m-d-squared" is added to the moment of inertia about the center of mass in this equation.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about Geico ads:
answer: insurance [accept specific types of insurance, since Geico does most of them]
parts: In a Geico ad, one of these animals asks a group of office workers to “guess what day it is.” At the end of that ad, a guitar-playing man named Ronnie says that people who save money with Geico are “happier than [one of these animals] on Wednesday.”
The Geico ad “Game night with a sloth” shows a group of people playing this game. A couple in the ad is unable to guess that a straight line is actually supposed to be a tandem bicycle.

According to Geico ads, fifteen minutes can save you fifteen percent or more on this service for cars or homes. This service, which Geico sells, is essentially a safeguard against financial loss in the event of damage.

bonuses.leadin: This site was excavated by Hiram Bingham in 1911. For ten points each:
parts: Name this Peruvian archaeological site, a fortress and royal palace built during the reign of Pachacuti.
Machu Picchu is a city from this South American empire. This empire, centered on the city of Cuzco, fell after the conquistador Francisco Pizarro had its last emperor, Atahualpa, killed.
Atahualpa ascended to power after winning a civil war against this brother of his. This man was captured by the forces of the general Quizquiz at the Battle of Quipaipan.

bonuses.leadin: These substances are ordered by strength of interaction in a spectrochemical series. For ten points each:
parts: Name these substances that form coordinate covalent bonds with central atoms or ions in a coordination complex. Chelation occurs when these substances attach at more than one location.
Ligands often attach to elements from this group in a coordination complex. This group of metals occupies the center of the periodic table and includes iron and silver.

Coordination complexes with four ligands often have a square planar geometry or this geometry. Molecules with sp3 [S-P-three] hybridization and no lone pairs form this geometry, which is possessed by methane.

bonuses.leadin: When you’re a naval commander and you’re all out of options, there’s only one thing to do: set your ships on fire and ram them into the enemy! For ten points each:
parts: Fire ships were used by the Dutch to destroy English warships during this event, during which Willem van Ghent and Michael de Ruyter led a daring attack on an English dockyard. The HMS Royal Charles was destroyed during this event.

During the lead up to this time period, the forces of Sun Quan and Liu Bei used fire ships to turn back the much larger force of Cao Cao at the Battle of Red Cliffs. This time period followed the collapse of the Han dynasty.
The British navy cleverly used fire ships to force this fleet sent by Philip II to break formation and scatter. This fleet was ironically referred to as the “Great and Most Fortunate Navy.”

bonuses.leadin: Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson’s observation of the cosmic microwave background radiation provided extremely strong evidence for this event. For ten points each:
answer: cosmic inflation [or cosmological inflation; accept inflationary epoch]
parts: Name this cosmological event in which the universe began as an extremely small region of space roughly 13.8 billion years ago.

The universe is thought to have rapidly expanded during this event, which started roughly 10 to the negative 36 seconds after the Big Bang. The isotropy and flatness of the universe is often attributed to this event.

The first epoch immediately following the creation of the universe, in which all four fundamental forces were united, is named for this German scientist. This physicist’s study of blackbodies caused him to postulate the quantization of energy.

bonuses.leadin: Each of the twelve sections of one novel titled after this substance begins with a recipe. For ten points each:
answer: chocolate [accept Like Water for Chocolate, accept Charlie and the Chocolate Factory]
parts: Name this foodstuff that, along with water, titles a 1989 novel by Laura Esquivel. A novel titled for a manufactory of this foodstuff features the bratty Veruca Salt.
Laura Esquivel is from this country, whose native son Octavio Paz memorialized its past Aztec culture in his poem Sunstone.

Carlos Fuentes, another Mexican novelist, fictionalized the disappearance of this author in his work The Old Gringo. This author wrote a short story in which a chess-playing automaton kills its builder, “Moxon’s Master.”

bonuses.leadin: This movie’s director requested that the central actress constantly be in motion for one of its scenes in which the glass wall of a phone booth surrounded by flames is shattered. For ten points each:
parts: Name this film starring Tippi Hedren, in which residents of Bodega Bay, California, are frequently attacked by the title creatures. This film is loosely based on a Daphne du Maurier short story with the same title.
The Birds is a film by this director of Psycho, North by Northwest, and Vertigo. This director, nicknamed “the master of suspense,” frequently cast Grace Kelly in his movies.

Hitchcock had earlier adapted Daphne du Maurier’s novel of this name into a film. In this movie, the title woman is never seen on screen, although she is discussed by Maxim de Winter and the housekeeper Mrs. Danvers.

bonuses.leadin: Skirmishes along the border between these two countries broke out in 2020 after one of them attempted to build a road in the region of Ladakh. For ten points each:
answer: People’s Republic of China AND Republic of India [accept Zhongguo for China and Bhārat Gaṇarājya for India, do NOT accept or prompt on “Republic of China”]
parts: Name these two countries, whose disputes over territory accelerated with skirmishes at Pangong Lake. Tensions increased between these two countries when it was reported that one country’s armed forces abducted citizens at Arunachal Pradesh.
Much of the territory contested between India and China lies along large swaths of this mountain range. This mountain range contains Everest, the highest peak in the world.
In response to the skirmishes, this prime minister of India quit the Chinese social media website Weibo after the Union Government banned 59 Chinese apps for alleged security concerns.

bonuses.leadin: The poem that describes this place is subtitled “Or, a vision in a dream: a fragment.” For ten points each:
answer: Xanadu [prompt on descriptive answers like Kubla Khan’s palace]
parts: Identify this palace described in the poem “Kubla Khan” as both a “sunny” and “stately pleasure-dome.”
This poet of “Kubla Khan” also wrote the line “water, water everywhere, nor any drop to drink,” in his long poem The Rime of the Ancient Mariner.
Coleridge worked with fellow Romantic poet William Wordsworth to publish this collection in 1798. The Rime of the Ancient Mariner and Tintern Abbey were first published in this poetry collection.

bonuses.leadin: The third movement of this composer’s piano concerto includes a folk fiddle and alludes to the Halling dance as a nod to his native Norway. For ten points each:
answer: Clara Josephine Wieck [or Clara Josephine Schumann; prompt on Schumann]
parts: Name this composer whose piano concerto begins with a timpani roll followed by a fortissimo tonic chord. This composer’s Peer Gynt suite contains a short section depicting trolls, “In the Hall of the Mountain King.”

Grieg’s piano concerto is in this note’s minor key, which has no sharps or flats and is the relative minor of C major. The concerto was inspired by Robert Schumann’s piano concerto which is also in this minor key.

Grieg first heard Robert Schumann’s piano concerto being performed by this pianist and composer of three Romances for Violin and Piano. Along with Robert Schumann, this composer advised and premiered many of Johannes Brahms’s piano works.

bonuses.leadin: Many religions named for these objects were founded in the 1950s as the term “flying saucer” grew in popularity. For ten points each:
answer: mass suicide [accept equivalents; prompt on descriptions of death]
parts: Name these objects which are any aerial vehicle whose origin is unknown. Conspiracy theorists often attribute sightings of these objects to alien spacecraft visiting Earth.

39 followers of the UFO religion Heaven’s Gate undertook this action in 1997 in order to board a UFO that they believed was trailing the Hale-Bopp comet. Members of the People’s Temple were ordered to take this action in Jonestown, Guyana in 1978.

A more well-known UFO religion, the Nation of Islam, rose to prominence under the leadership of this man. This man established the Nation’s belief in a “Mother Plane,” a UFO that visited the prophet Ezekiel.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about controversies involving American officer James Wilkinson:
parts: James Wilkinson worked under Horatio Gates, who this group chose to replace George Washington as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army. Wilkinson later helped force the resignation of this group’s namesake by providing Washington with incriminating evidence.

As Governor of the Louisiana Territory, Wilkinson later partnered with this man to plan the formation of a new country in the Southwest U.S. An electoral deadlock involving this non-Virginian politician led to the passage of the Twelfth Amendment.

While a captain in the Continental Army, Wilkinson led reinforcements to Quebec to support this besieging general. Later, this famed traitor’s plan to hand over West Point to the British was foiled by the capture of his associate John Andre.
